title: Cladogram orangutan gorilla chimp bonobo human 2

content.description:
The TAS2R38 gene encodes a receptor protein that influences the ability to taste bitterness. The gene has two alleles: a dominant, wild-type allele that enables an individual (taster) to taste bitterness and a recessive, mutant allele that interferes with the ability of an individual (nontaster) to taste bitterness. Three single nucleotide mutations in the coding region of the TAS2R38 gene are associated with the nontaster allele. The nucleotides present at the three positions are shown in the table below.

content.question: Which of the following scientific questions will best help researchers determine when the nontaster allele arose in the evolutionary history of the selected primates?

choices.label: How does the nontaster allele contribute to individual fitness?
Does the nontaster allele exist in any nonhuman primate populations?
What caused the mutations in the TAS2R38 gene?
How do the mutations in the nontaster allele affect the structure of the resulting protein?

content.answer: Does the nontaster allele exist in any nonhuman primate populations?
